Heummm
Yes,, you are right.
An auction is an auction if it is Ebay or Sothebys/Christies.
Anyway.... it is a pitty for the people who want to buy or sale 
items.

John



--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, samurai@x wrote:
> 
> Complain using this form:
> 
> http://pages.ebay.com/help/policies/replica-counterfeit.html
> 
> Ebay will take them down in 24 hours.
> 
> There is only one reason that Ebay doesn't go after these guys in 
a much
> harder fashion. They're accomplices to the sale. Every fake sold 
means
> money in Ebay's pocket. If you turn on the lights while the thief 
and
> his accomplice are robbing your house, the accomplice suddenly 
turns
> into a vigilante and is glad to help you catch the thief... 
> 
> That's the one and only reason Ebay doesn't do anything about it.
> 
> On the flip side of the coin...
> 
> There is a saying, "It's impossible to cheat an honest man."
> 
> Everyone on Ebay wants to get a steal. They want to buy your item 
for
> less than it is worth, and if you ask a fair price few will go to
> you. They will flock to those that appear to be offering discounted
> items though, often times cutting deals outside of ebay, and all 
they do
> is screw themselves. Their own greed means they end up with these
> valueless pieces of junk. 
> 
> Even armed with a little information, if they see someone who 
doesn't
> appear to know what they're selling, how many of them send an 
email and
> say, "Hey dude, that junky violin you found in your grandpa's 
attic is
> really a Stradivarius. You should get it authenticated and sell it 
at
> Sotheby's, pay off your mortgage and be able to send your kid to a 
good
> university."
> 
> Very few.
> 
> So when you go out of your way to inform them, often times you 
take away
> the mystery and the treasure hunting mentality takes them
> elsewhere. Right into the hands of the scammers.
> 
> They want to buy something from you of extreme value, and not pay 
for
> it. So they find someone who looks like they're providing this to 
them. 
> 
> It's not only with swords, but it's with diamonds... other 
gemstones,
> watches, everything. I sold some gold coins once, and I had no end 
of
> people offering to do me a favor and give me 20% *less* than the 
market
> price of gold if I would sell to them now and end the auction.
> 
> Gold is the one thing that has a well understood value in the 
world, and
> even on ebay auctions will end at the market price of gold
> consistently. The price of gold is less a reflection on the value 
of
> gold then it is on the value of paper money. 
> 
> These people were effectively offering me 80 cents if I would give 
them
> a dollar bill. There is no mentality there for a fair deal, just a 
hope
> that they can get something for less than it is valued.
> 
> For both reasons above, junk will continue to be put on ebay and 
the
> auctions will be well attended. People will buy first and ask 
questions
> later. And ebay will turn a blind eye to everything.
> 
> - darcy
> 
> <saemonjonosuke@h...> writes:
> 
> > Hi,
> > It is getting more 'funny' with this Chinese 'dealers' on Ebay.
> > 2 weeks ago I put a tsuba from Mastsugu on Ebay,, many people 
watch 
> > and bid on it.
> 
> > But now,,, some Chinese dealer copy my title and discription and 
put 
> > it on his 3 *^#@ tsuba's......
> > Please see these items.
> 
> > Item number: 2578865338 / 2578866848 / 2578869530 
>  
> > I don't understand that Ebay doesn't do anything about this.
> 
> > John
